astute one provides the software s to
payroll so that cell SAS app which runs
on AWS and our clients use that for all
sorts of recruitment time shading
payroll and invoicing activities for

casual staff full time staff we provide

is senior DevOps engineer but as you

cloud architect I was brought on to take
our monolithic payroll software
application out of traditional data
center and and lift and shifted on to
aid up there
absolutely yes so our first stage of
moving to AWS was our lift and shift we
didn't make a lot of changes to the
application we made a few necessary ones
but but other than that it was just pick
it up drop it in and hope for the best
and for the most part that did work
really well our second phase of that is
container izing our application so we're
moving to kubernetes within the next
couple of months and we're doing that on
eks from the operation side we're
looking at get container Eisinger
software so putting that onto eks so
that we can move a lot faster in terms
of releases so we can have our
developers using the same environment
that their production servers use and
they can also contribute to that
environment so the environment that we
run in is no longer dictated by the
operations team it's something that the
developers are very much involved in
because they're using it as well as we
containerize within looking at speeding
up a lot of our back-end storages so we
store a lot in MySQL at the moment in my
scales a great relational database it's
not great for every single type of data
under the Sun so we're looking at moving
a lot out to say Redis in elastication
and also some searchable data into
elasticsearch so that we can leverage
the benefits of those products we find
it really easy to do on AWS because well
I don't have to learn how to administer
a Redis server or an elastication server
I just need to learn the AWS API is that
controller and that's a lot simpler and
then our next phase after that which
will be over the next probably year or
two we'll be starting to separate our
application into separate micro services
and likely running a lot of those in
their own containers possibly even as
service workloads as well it's great to
be part of learning what everyone else
is doing and talking to people because
we all have slightly different
experience you can't solve a problem on
your own so as soon as you bring another
way of thinking about it into the mix
and up solving problems much quicker the
variety of slack groups around have been
really helpful for that and it's such a
friendly kind of style that these
communities have you can just pop on
there and say this has happened and I'm
trying to think about the best solution
you know what do you think about this
this or this and you'll instantly get a
bunch of opinions for people who have
possibly even been through at the same
thing but
for and it's a really great way to then
leverage what AWS can provide to then
you know go back to the boss and say
here are some solutions I have and you
